comments.commentBody:
" ...because the no-fly zone we established around the Kurdish area helped keep Saddam from wiping out those people entirely)."

Good to point this out ... while we sometimes do things which are plain wrong, it would be nice if critics acknowledged that, many times, we do the right thing.

There are two other reasons why Tunisia and mini-Kurdistan are doing so well: they're both relatively small and their populations are ethnically and culturally heterogeneous.  Still, the West's relative lack of interference in both of these areas is as good a reason as any (I say "relative" because the no-fly zone we established around the Kurdish area helped keep Saddam from wiping out those people entirely).
RAM TOUGH is an advertising slogan for the truck brand.

To help you understand today's kids, when you applied to university in 1967, there were about 200 million people in the country. Now there are almost 320 million. You can do the math there.

But now guestimate how much more competition comes from international students, because I don't know. But it wasn't much of an issue in 1967. Or 1997. It is now.

And it has become increasingly important to have a university degree, even for jobs where it was considered unnecessary in the past.

But university admissions numbers have not increased anywhere close to the increase in number of applicants. Restricting supply when there is an increasing demand creates desperation among would-be customers and increases the prestige of the supplier. And allows the supplier to increase prices at a greater rate.

Universities want to make people desperate to get in because it makes them look better and allows them to charge more. Then the admissions office can say "gee, we have to turn away all these great people..." when it's the university's own actions causing this to happen.
Economists don't have the answers. Only inventors do. We need to fund more basic science to give them the means to invent new things.

To assume that slow growth is bad seems a little twisted. We could chill for awhile. People are nicer when they have less to do.

Anyway, It's hardly news that wars spur economic growth or that they help diversify the gene pool. What would be news is if humans found a way to go against their nature and re-channel their destructiveness -- If they woke up from being heroes and freed themselves from oligarchs, God, or the planets. Maybe Gurdjieff got it right when he claimed that human suffering is food for the moon.

Only old people like me will get the Beatles reference.
Or, perhaps, Henry the horse.
For the benefit of Mr. Kite there will be a show tonight, on disaster foreign policy.

Yes. War is good for the super rich but very very very bad for the poor and near poor. They die and those who don't suffer the rest of their lives.  while the rich get richer. A headline like this should be banned from this and every other paper in the country. Besides we have had continuous war since Vietnam and the economy sitnks.

comments.userDisplayName: Robert S. Stewart, CEO, AIC Inc.
comments.commentBody: There have been impressive technological inventions that can bring affordable resources from remote locations into the hands of the majority who will live in cities. The Hybrid Airship designed and built by Lockheed Martin is NOT a war ship or attack aircraft, but the most ingeneous invention meant to move resources around a hungry world without building trillions of dollars of additional infrastructure.
The Growth Model is out anyway.  No more easy resources, quasi slave labor or remaining atmosphere to pollute.  Time to start to try to understand sustainability instead.

comments.userDisplayName: Robert S. Stewart, CEO, AIC Inc.
comments.commentBody: It might well turn out that low or no growth, maintaining the status quo, is the price of peace. I suspect most people on Earth would rather have no growth in return for a longer life, no matter how poor. It is hose who thrive on gluttony, richesse and power who impose death on others who would rather simply survive than fight their wars.

Did anyone read he entire article? His conclusion is not that we should go to war. He is saying that less economic growth may be a necessary sacrifice for peace. This article does not encourage war. It does not say war is good. It tries to explain the reason behind our economic stagnation. The author could be wrong, but we never says anything immoral.

When the US does not face an existential threat (late 19th century, post-cold war), the federal government becomes increasingly dysfunctional because there is no threat to unify the politicians.  Without the Russkies threatening to bury us we are free to engage in class warfare, ideological warfare, racial warfare amongst ourselves.  We are free to spend on butter rather than guns, which makes both government and the governed rather fat and out of shape.  The public and its representatives reacts to outside threats by doing whatever it takes (balance the budget, educate our children, provide an efficient welfare or medical system) to make the country strong.  If the country does not need to be strong, then it's every man for himself.  It's just human nature, but not something to be proud of.

American born Korean here. I make trips out to Korea once every couple years to see family. Maybe it's because I've eaten it since I was a kid but the smell and taste really don't offend me. Yes, it's a little acidic but is delicious when prepared correctly. As people have said below, it is usually marinated in a spicy sauce that actually complements the smell and texture of the fish. There are far stranger dishes that I will not even touch when I go there (and I will eat anything). Take a whiff of a bowl of mudfish soup or blood intestine soup and you'll see what I mean. Better yet, take a stroll through an open air market in a rural part of South Korea. Now THAT is a treat.
Mmmmm, bierkase on toast with Miracle Whip!
Do I have this right? When you taste the ammonia, you are actually consuming the animal's urine?

I attended college at the tail end of the legacy era, when a name like Bush or Gore would gain admission for mediocre students. I turned down the great eastern school to go to a "public ivy" - it somehow felt right, and was much cheaper. For a time afterwards, I naively thought that everyone at Great Eastern must be at least as bright and probably smarter than my colleagues at public U. Then I met some of these folks, who were uniformly self-assured but often much less literate and numerate than my crowd. I went on to work with many Ivies in my academic and professional career (and I even married one!), but no legacies - not a one.

Ah, those WASP values!

It was not simply the British being know-it-alls, not that they weren't ignorant and presumptuous; but they pursued a set imperial practice of divide-and-rule, which sometimes even worked in the short term, if at the cost of many fuzzy-wuzzy lives about which the empire cared not at all. In the longer run, well, we're seeing it now.
Fully agree.  Bush/Cheney and the neocon either did not understand the history of the region or ignored it for the purpose of American hegemony in the region.

As usual Dothat tries to deflect the blame for the problems in Iraq, Iran, & Syria, away from preceding Republican administrations.

It was the British who divided up the Middle East as countries, not recognizing tribal identities. They were warned by Lawrence of Arabia to not do so, but typically British know it all took precedence.

The Kurds should have been given a homeland then, but were ignored. Then G.W. Bush convinces congress to let him invade and occupy this territory, and he does so. Then he sends Paul Bremmer with plenipotentiary powers to build a new nation. Bremmer fires all the members of the Baath party because it was Husein's party, which in order to be a teacher, public servant, or military officer, they had to join.

He stripped the country of the people who knew how to run it. He was told by the upper military leadership not to, but Bush, Rumsfeld, Cheney, and Wolfowitz backed him up, allowing him to do so.

The Kurds, who want American help and are allies were again left out, as Bush acquiesced to the Turks

Now these displaced Sunnis have returned and are a formidable force. They have the knowledge and intelligence to overthrow Maliki, who is despised by most of the Iraqis. And as usual, some loud mouth GOP politicians are making Mr. Obama responsible. the WSJ has an editorial doing just that in today's paper.

How despicable can you get? How much propaganda will the public believe? How many lies and prevarications can the GOP concoct?
He was right, none of these loud mouth politicians can be trusted to keep their mouths shut.

You're technically correct, and Obama did violate the law.  But of course, this law was passed exclusively to handicap Obama.  I am far more disturbed by Obama's other violations, such as the warrantless wiretapping and his nasty prosecution of true whistleblowers.

Dr. K,

When you said that you were going to have dinner with "business economists", I started worrying. Business economists do not have a grip on how to broadly share the benefits of an economy. Those who choose that title demonstrate that they don't understand the nature of the US and Global challenge of creating a system that will "fairly" distribute income. Even though the US is increasing its total income, it is clearly not being shared with the people who contributed to producing it. There is no wage pressure because when earnings come under pressure, business enterprises simply globally race to the bottom.

I agree that we are not closing the gap between actual & potential output. Incredibly, the concept of "the new norm" has surfaced to see if it will stick. This is completely nuts. My plea, don't join the groupthink on this issue.

The US suffers from lack of imagination. We as a society have not been able to come up with a BIG IDEA that will capture the public's imagination, all we can think of is nickle & dime investments, & most are copycat exercises in the use of cell phones.

Global Warming is a "sputnik" level threat & we can't seem to get going on technology to address this threat. I write often of launching a Superconducting Interstate Maglev network for carrying trucks & passengers. I also write often about a Maglev Space Launch system to build low-cost solar generation in orbit for beaming power to Earth.

I don't accept the "new normal."

Was there something special about this drone attack, that you single it out for mention? Or do you join us honest Americans (trying, anyway) in condemning all drone attacks on helpless civilians who happen to be in the way, or mistaken for enemies, as well as all executions of American citizens without due process (by Obama and Bush)? I hope you do, and thank you if you do.

I hope you also worry that somehow only Americans are thought entitled to due process under the current interpretation of our Constitution, while Canadians and other are helpless victims.
I'm sure selective colleges would love to know where their applicants "are going with their futures," but exactly how would one predict that of any 17 year old?

In a sea of seemingly similar applicants, all of whom have stellar test scores and grades, and desperately desiring to get admitted into an elite university, admissions committees naturally look to the essay as a differentiating factor (along with other demographics).  But essays are no more a glimpse into the workings of a successful college-bound mind than grades and test scores. Too many 4.2+, 2400 SAT, AP-laden applicants don't make for a very diverse campus, and are not necessarily a predictor of scholastic or future success. I say, reduce the primacy of grades and test scores and essays, and look atPerhaps a better measure would be to place less emphasis on numbers and writing and look at not just from where applicants are coming, but also at where they are going with their futures.

People reportedly voted for George W. Bush because he was the candidate they'd prefer to have a beer with. Many American voters are just flat-out stupid.

But there's hope. Dubya lost the popular vote in 2000, after all. He needed help stealing the election from the Republicans on the Supreme Court and from his brother Jeb. And the only reason he was "re-elected" in 2004 was that he shamefully exploited the terror of 9/11, lying us into the Iraq war so he could run as a "war president."

Who you vote for is critically important. Acting as if it isn't a matter of life and death brought us, in our own lifetime, the worst president in our nation's history.
And she didn't vote for the Bush Iraq war the way independent Hill did. Look over there today. This is the vision of the next president?

Can we stick to a candidate's positions and record and leave off  petty character assassinations? She (might be) running for president, not for Best Friend. I don't care how imperious she is, I care what she'll do.  I'd like the chance to vote for Elizabeth Warren because I think I like her positions better -- not because the girls in the high school locker room think she's nicer or more sincere.

Pam,

I think I would add that our first responsibility is to call for a "Cease Fire" and a conference of all parties to see what the real problems are. It is probably economic injustice based on religious affiliation but humans have dealt with this before.

How can the narrator say that Common Core was hailed by experts and teachers? Very few teachers were involved in the adaption of the Common Core and as the Washington Post reported, Bill Gates did more to push this than any educator. Many teachers had problems with it from day one yet their concerns fell on deaf ears.

The principal in the video is also ignorant of the facts. Children in early childhood learn about plants, tornadoes and landforms. My kinder students learned about different habitats. And we used fiction to connect children to scientific themes. We need to go back to exploration and hands-on experiment when it comes to science not reading non-fiction.

The teacher remarks she now has "better materials", but what she really means is she has finally received her test prep materials. Last year many NYC schools did not receive materials until months after school started. As for her "patriotic duty", what was she doing before the Common Core? Wasn't she following NYS standards which were excellent? I really have a problem with any video that looks like an advertisement for Common Core and gives a lot of misinformation about the NYC Standards.
Are you sure the skate has enough life left in him after his "merry fight"? I fear that many catch and release fish swim off to die later of exhaustion or predators.
I once ate durian. After you get past the smell it's pretty good...like a deliciously nasty cheese. I inhaled through my mouth instead of my nose.
